labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Key derivation
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: Key derivation and blinding are sometimes used interchangeably, especially in the context of BIP32, but they seem to be different functionalities. In particular, key derivation works like so. Assume the key pair `x` and `xG`, for scalar `x` and generator `G`. Deriving a key with index `j` from `(x, xG)` can be done by computing a new private key `x_j = Hash(xG || j) + x` and the corresponding public key as `xG + x_jG`. This computation is deterministic and allows the public key to be derived based on _public_ information only, a property referred to in the literature as [public derivation](https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/704.pdf). In contrast, one could generate `x_j` as `x_j = Hash(x || j) + x`.

issues.title: Additive and multiplicative blinding
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
The current draft supports multiplicative blinding, which means that blinding and unblinding requires knowledge of the _private_ blind value. Additive blinding may also be feasible, especially for other signature algorithms [like ECDSA](https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1330.pdf). It generally works like so. Assume a private key `x` and public key `xG`, for generator `G`. Additive blinding generates secret key `x+b`, for random scalar `b`, and corresponding public key `xG + bG`. Note that these line up since `(x+b)G = xG + bG`.

This has some useful properties, like being able to blind and unblind using only the _public_ key. However, that may not be appropriate for all applications.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closing this for now. We can always revisit adding this functionality in the future.

issues.title: Other signature schemes
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: The draft currently focuses on EdDSA as specified in RFC8032. We might want to consider widening scope and targeting other signature schemes and curves, e.g., ECDSA over secp256k1.

issues.title: Abstraction properties
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: [This paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/704.pdf) captures some properties we might want quite nicely, including deterministic secret generation and public derivation (deriving public values without private information). Should the abstraction support both derivation based on public and private information? That is, deriving a key with a private value, and deriving a key with a public value.

issues.title: Rename BlindSign
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: This isn't a blind signature. It's rather "sign using a blinded private key." There's probably a better way to describe this operation.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @jedisct1, any thoughts?

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body:
Indeed, calling it a blind signature would be confusing.

`BlindKeySign` maybe?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Yeah, that's better! Do you want to send a PR? =)

issues.title: Revisit clamping for EdDSA variant
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
@tedeaton correctly observes that clamping the high-order bit in the EdDSA variants has the effect of making the resulting blind scalar distinguishable from a truly random scalar. Importantly, clamping that bit splits the set of blinded public keys in half -- one half where the bit is 0, which might be in the image set of the blind function, and the other half where the bit is 1, which definitely won't be in the image set of the blind function due to the clamp. This means that every blinded public key basically leaks one bit.

This leak could be exploited to recover the pre-image of the blind function. See [this gist](https://gist.github.com/chris-wood/a68c18aedf0914d13b8966f45f2d1ae7) for a toy example where we can recover the pre-image of blind given (a) sufficiently many random blind samples and (b) enough pre-computation work done by an attacker. The amount of work is substantial, i.e., on the order of O(group order), but we should probably acknowledge that this can be improved in practice with more sophisticated pre-computation or targeted attacks. 

In any case, I think we ought to remove the clamping step for the blind scalar to ensure that it's a truly random scalar each time. For ed25519, this is as simple as changing the whole clamping step from:

```
bytes[0] &= 248 // clear cofactor
bytes[31] &= 63
bytes[31] |= 64
```

to 

```
bytes[0] &= 248 // clear cofactor
```

comments.author: jedisct1
comments.body:
Do we even need to clear the low bits at all?

We only perform a scalar multiplication of the base point with the blind scalar, so why would the cofactor be an issue?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Great question! I think you're right in that we don't need to clear anything here. The generator will have prime order (by definition), and multiplying it by any scalar value won't change that order. So we can simplify further and just interpret the unclamped byte array as a little-endian integer. =)

issues.title: Evaluate impact of Related-Key Attacks against ECDSA-BlindKeySign
issues.author: FredericJacobs
issues.body:
We need more security analysis on ECDSA-BlindKeySign and related functions. There might be some risks related to the blinding we need to dig deeper into.

[This paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2015/1135.pdf) Sec 4.2 doesn't directly translate to our scheme but it could be that similar attacks apply.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> We need more security analysis on ECDSA-BlindKeySign and related functions. There might be some risks related to the blinding we need to dig deeper into.

Hmm, can you elaborate on this? A blinded signing key is indistinguishable and independently distributed from the unblinded signing key, so I'm not sure I see a problem here. In particular, I don't think there is a relation between the blinded and unblinded keys, by construction. Perhaps I'm missing something.

comments.author: tedeaton
comments.body:
I think this paper (in particular section 4.1) does point out a potential avenue of attack, especially on additive blinding (as mentioned in #2 ). The attack would allow an adversary (who knows the blinding factor) to take a message-signature pair issued under a blinded public key blpk, and transform it into a valid message-signature pair under the identity public key (or possibly under another blinded public key?).

This came up in a construction of a lattice based blinding scheme [I worked on](https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/963.pdf), which also used an 'additive' blinding method. The solution we used there should also here, which is to include the public key in the hash function when generating the challenge. Thankfully, EdDSA already does this, which should make signatures significantly more immune to this kind of malleability.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> I think this paper (in particular section 4.1) does point out a potential avenue of attack, especially on additive blinding (as mentioned in https://github.com/chris-wood/draft-wood-cfrg-eddsa-blinding/issues/2 ). The attack would allow an adversary (who knows the blinding factor) to take a message-signature pair issued under a blinded public key blpk, and transform it into a valid message-signature pair under the identity public key (or possibly under another blinded public key?).

This is only for additive blinding, correct? The draft here currently only discusses multiplicative blinding.

comments.author: tedeaton
comments.body: Yes, the attack as described there would only be for additive blinding, and it isn't obvious (to me) how it could be adapted for multiplicative.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @tlepoint do you think we can close this?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closing.

issues.title: Mention public key signing as related-key attack mitigation
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
One standard mitigation to the related-key forgery attack is to sign the public key alongside the message. This then requires the verifier to include the public key as part of the input message, which changes the verification interface. Nevertheless, it seems useful to note. 

cc @kwantam for separately noting this! 🙏

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Fixed directly on `main`.

issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
It was used [in this work](https://eprint.iacr.org/2020/676.pdf). Section 3 discusses the construction for ECDSA, for example. 

Thanks to @kwantam for pointing this out!

issues.title: Add more motivation
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: It's been observed by several people that the motivation for this primitive is not particularly clear. We should motivate with additional applications (like #23), including at least one concrete use case. We could use a simplified version of the rate-limited draft for that.

issues.author: dvorak42
issues.body:

> In some settings, in is useful to produce signatures with a given key pair (sk, pk) such that the resulting signature is not linkable to pk without knowledge of a particular witness r. That is, given pk corresponding to sk, witness r, and a message signature, one can determine if the signature was indeed produced using sk.

In section 5.1, maybe explicitly call out halfing to a 57-byte buffer?

issues.title: Make 'unblind' optional?
issues.author: tedeaton
issues.body:
Our definition of key-blinding includes the unblind operation such that `Unblind( Blind( pk, bk), bk) = pk`. This suits applications where `bk` is private, but their are applications where this is not the case. Notably, the use of key-blinding in Tor has `bk` being a public value, informed by the daily consensus, and unblinding is impossible, making the blinding process more one-way. 

Should the spec include this option, and discuss that the choice reflects whether the `bk` value is private or not? This would likely also mean that multiple security models are necessary, depending on the configuration used.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
Rather than say it's an optional function, I think we could simply say that one needs `bk` to invoke `UnblindPublicKey`. If an application keeps it private, then this can't be done.

On the Tor point, it sounds like this functionality doesn't really line up with what's presented here. In particular, the constructions we provide allow one to invoke `UnblindPublicKey` provided they have `bk`. How does Tor prevent this from happening?

comments.author: tedeaton
comments.body: In Tor's version of key-blinding, the scalar is generated from the hash of `bk` and the identity public key `pk`, so that both are needed to blind / unblind.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Got it 👍 I think we could update the constructions here to do something similar without any functional change to the Privacy Pass protocol. @kwantam, would this be compatible with the airdrop application?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: This was also raised in Ian's review, so we'll use this issue to track its resolution.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
One construction that Ian mentioned on the list was the following:

```
pkS = H(bk, pkR, timestamp) * pkR
```

This isn't reversible unless you know all inputs to H. The constructions in the draft currently only hash `bk` into the scalar, and then choose to make that available (or not) for the purposes of inversion: 

```
pkS = H(bk) * pkR
```

What if we generalized the construction a bit to accommodate more domain separation?

```
pkS = H(bk, dst) * pkR
```

One could then set `dst = pkR`, `dst = timestamp`, `dst = pkR || timestamp`, or whatever else made sense. 

@jedisct1, @tlepoint, @tedeaton, @FredericJacobs: thoughts?

comments.author: tedeaton
comments.body: Yes, I agree, that seems like the right generalization to me.

comments.author: tlepoint
comments.body:
I also agree that this seems like a desirable generalization. Note however that the statement 

> This isn't reversible unless you know all inputs to H. 

is a bit strong. If you know `bk, pkR` but not `timestamp`, you can still reverse it by brute-forcing the value. An argument that would claim irreversibility needs to consider the entropy of the `dst` somehow.

issues.title: Correctness conditions
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
> Again in 3, the correctness condition requires the existence of UnblindPublicKey, which may not exist.

> Aren't you missing another correctness condition at the end of Section 3?  Namely, that public keys produced with BlindPublicKey will correctly verify signatures produced with BlindKeySign (using the standard signature verification function)?

issues.title: Editorial improvements from Ian's review
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
> At the start of 3, now you _insist_ that bk is secret: "Similar to the signing key, the blinding key is also a private key that remains
secret."  But then what of the critical property above that distinguishes key blinding from "generate a fresh key"?  If no one other than the key holder can blind or unblind public keys on their own, so that the key holder has to actually deliver the new public key each time, then why _not_ use one of the two trivial constructions above?

- [ ] Drop "remains secret" since `bk` is used for unblinding keys.

> "two separate key signing keys": you don't have key signing keys; presumably you meant "two independent signing keys", or something like that?

- [ ] Use "independent" instead of "separate".

> Nit: "a random scalar in the P-256 group": in my mind, "the P-256 group" is the group of elliptic curve points, not the scalar field.  But hopefully no one will get confused by this wording.

- [ ] Clarify P-256 group wording.

> It's a little jarring that the list of four new functionalities is repeated in Section 3, just a page or so after it first appears in Section 1.

- [ ] Only include list once.

> In Section 4.2, in which of steps 1 and 2 do you or don't you do buffer pruning?  It sounds like you do in step 1 but not in step 2?

- [ ] Make clear what steps prune and which don't.

> In Section 5.2, it seems more explicit that step 1 and step 2 both *do* do buffer pruning.  (Except that contradicts Section 5.1, which suggests it does *not*?)  Is Ed448 intended to be different from Ed25519 here?

- [ ] Make language consistent with ed25519 variant.

issues.title: Key blinding spec should specify serialization scheme
issues.author: cathieyun
issues.body:
Currently, there is no serialization scheme specified for the messages being sent, or the test vectors. Specifying a serialization scheme is important for interoperability and correctness (eg using a constant-length serialization scheme if concatenating multiple serialized elements).

The OPRFs spec has a good example of serialization specifications, eg:
https://cfrg.github.io/draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf/draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf.html#name-oprfp-384-sha-384
